job_title: Senior Admissions Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: High salary, great benefits, team atmosphere, you get to help lots of people while being compensated properly.
cons: Sometimes you had to work weekends and during the week until 8pm

pros: None, there are no pros
cons: Worst job ever. Regret completely

pros: Their training was good for new employees
cons: You had quote to hit for new admissions. It’s hard to sell a college just to hit quota

pros: All were disappointing, short lived....
cons: Poor management. Latch of growth opportunity, and poor benefits.

job_title: Business Office Manager in Denver, CO
pros: You have the ability to take classes entirely online.
cons: You are going to receive career advice that isn't true. Admissions is going to hound you endlessly until you enroll. Then, you are going to pay more for a bachelor's degree than if you had gotten your doctorate.

job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Denver, CO
pros: The Co-workers were the best part of the job. I meet and worked with a lot of really amazing people working at West wood.Co-workers were amazing, helpful and friendly. I am grateful for gaining valuable sales experience that will be needed for future work with a real company. Yes, you do have the opportunity to help students change their lives through education, however you end up hurting far more students, than actually helping, in the process. You are responsible for getting students into school that are not ready for school, don't have the computer skills for online classes, no time for for school or really don't have the ability or desire to make it through school.
cons: The admissions positions at West wood college is a revolving door for employees.Most employee's are let go within the first year due to not meeting their goals( Number of students they enroll) The metrics and standards set by the school are so tough that only a few representatives are able to meet them. The main goal is to enroll as many students and have them start for classes so that the school can collect federal financial aid from the students. Then get those students to take out loans to cover the remainder potion for the extremely overpriced school.  For-profits schools in general, including West wood, needs a complete top to bottom overhaul or needs to cease to exist altogether.

review_title: I've been very impressed by the progress of the institution and I support the direction it is headed.
pros: I've been lucky to work closely with people who genuinely care about doing the right thing and serving the students and graduates of the college. Every campus I've visited has an extremely positive and welcoming environment, run by people who believe in their students. There are so many programs that are created to enhance the culture of the organization and add to the community of everyone who works for and attends the school. I've worked for other companies that have reacted poorly to some pretty challenging situations and the way I've observed Westwood handling their specific challenges is very impressive and promising. No organization is perfect, but the way the college aspires to be better is reflective of the truly good people who make it all work from the ground up.
cons: The organization has some more work to do to build the culture of its employees, but I've seen improvement over the years and I believe it will continue to get better. There will always be individuals who choose to focus on the negatives in any organization, but overall if the leadership team listens to the faculty and staff and continues to make improvements that lead to better outcomes for students, I can't see any significant cons.

review_title: I enjoy the "hands off" experience and flexibility in my schedule as I teach Online.
pros: Good Chairperson support (they are the direct managers over adjunct faculty). Good Student Advisor support. Flexible schedule. This is the Online school. Many of the adult learners are amazing.
cons: No raises for adjunct faculty. No vacations for adjunct faculty with any substitute teaching. There used to be substitute teachers for online but this service was taken away. If you travel you have to take a computer with you and work late at night while vacationing with others during the day. There is a lack of technical support for problems with student Webspace and the Adobe Connect rooms. The Adobe Connect rooms for live meetings disconnect sharing frequently and disconnect all together at least one time during meetings. Instructors used to have a lot more input with respect to the class designs and which classes were taught and added to the curriculum.

review_title: Strong Educational Product with Enticing Chicago Experience for Out of State HS Students.
job_title: High School Field Admissions Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Pay, Reviews, Bachelor Programs Offered for HS Students, Training.
cons: Manager bullied staff. The week after qualifying and receiving a $2k raise after my first 6 months my HSDOA said multiple times he really hoped he made the right decision and that I would prove it. Also would call early on Saturday and demand activity and make statements against family time church etc. and would often use cuss words inappropriately on one on one calls. Staff meetings he was a lot better because others were around. It is sad I had this experience because after 11 months I needed to resign after the above tactics and him saying "I never jumped $20k in 1 yr by sitting on my ass eating Cheetos watching movies with my wife and kids I had to get out there and work!" also the straw that broke the camels back was "I love God with all my heart but God doesn't pay my f*****g bills" Although an amazing salesman and great trainer who I learned a lot from and enjoyed everything about the product and company I was selling for, he was just too old school bi-polar militant leadership style that although I was 5 hrs away in St Louis recruiting for Chicago and making it happen needed to re-sign to keep my values in perspective.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Calumet City, IL
pros: some great people to work with. training offered in denver.
cons: sales, with sales quotas and tons of cold calling. You have to enroll so many students a week, month, period whether they are right for the school or not. The staff surrounding the enrollment process are under-qualified, underpaid, and overworked which means that you end up doing everyone else's job. Often it will take someone in student services 20 minutes just to respond to your original request or question and if something is missing for "your student" you need to fix it. Hand holding is a necessity and the show rate for appts is around 20%. Leads are given to you but it is based on how your performance is which means you constantly have to prove yourself in order to do your job. Getting on the wrong side of management means that you will be cutoff and it will be impossible to hit your quota's and do your job.

review_title: Worked hard established myself as core subject matter expert and in the end it was a fulfilling teaching experience.
job_title: Full-Time Instructor in Calumet City, IL
pros: Working with the students and helping them overcome their difficulties. This is the real perk to the job.
cons:
Even though my track record was perfect and never called off in 8 years they let me go because they couldn't offer me 3 classes.

Complete hands off administration. 

Disrespectful and aggressive financial aid staff interrupting class to intercept students to fill out financial aide forms, etc. 

Cost of school is astronomical. 80k for a bachelor's degree. Many students never see that salary upon graduation and default on their loans.

No vacation, No matching 401k.

review_title: Admissions Dept in need of overhaul
pros: The actual team members I work with are fantastic. Management was a different story. Several years ago, there was an opportunity to make more money and move around in the company. However, for the past 3 years, there have been salary freezes.
cons:
Unrealistic goals and terrible leads; Rude management personalities and micro-management with time management throughout the day. The Admissions team was required to use their 30 min break time to use the restroom. 

Selling a 75K degree over the phone in 2 hours time; with all the negative press and disclosures, and consistent  IT issues was not a good experience. 

HR dept with little compassion for representatives - and more aligned with Director's agendas and disciplinary actions, than fairness.

review_title: Felt a little morally bankrupt as an Admissions Rep
pros:
Payrate is decent
Great co-workers who seem to believe in what they are doing
My supervisor was respnisive and communicative...you knew where you stood.
Sales experience (make no mistake...this is a SALES job)
cons:
You are actively participating in bankrupting students who really have not business/ need to pay $40,000+ for an education that probably will not result in a position that will allow them to payback that loan
They say your pay is not based on enrollments....but it most assuredly is.
Looking back...I feel dirty and dishonest after working in admissions here.  They are very good at cheerleading the school, the system and thier sales staff...and I bought it.  Now I am ashamed that I did.

pros: Decent pay. Lots of great people work there, but I got the feeling that most of them didn't have a choice. There were also a few great instructors.
cons: On paper, my job was an Admissions Representative. In practice, I was a sales person. There was incredible pressure to recruit students and convince them to take out tens of thousands of dollars in loans at any cost. I was told that veterans were easy recruits because they have "Uncle Sam money" to pay for school. And once you convinced a student to enroll, you had 14 days to convince them to remain enrolled. There was a saying: "As**s in classes for 14 days," which referred to the requirement that the college wouldn't receive money from government-issued student loans unless the student is there for a minimum of 14 days. If they didn't stay those 14 days, I couldn't count that enrollment towards my enrollment quota. In the end, I was fired for not enrolling enough people. It was the best thing that could have happened to me.

pros: Over my long stay with the campus I have come to know a lot of talented and passionate students and faculty members.  Insurance and salary used to be fairly good.  I had the opportunity to open my lab so that groups of students could voluntarily work long hours on extracurricular projects.  In the past, I would rate the workplace as a positive place where there is no shortage of opportunities to engage students.
cons: Regulatory and legal problems abound and the student body is dwindling.  There is little need for instructors since the student body has shrunken so drastically that it is likely that the campus will close.  In recent years there has been a reduction in force and there are practically no benefits.  Ratings will be very low if I base them on the current state of the campus.

review_title: Good place to get experience but do not plan on staying long term.
pros: Flexible hours, free parking, gym on site
cons: Salaries are way under market which is probably why they cannot hold onto anybody that is worth anything. Raises are pretty much non-existent and bonus for one year was a 15 dollar Mc Donalds gift card. When somebody leaves then they just dump extra work on who ever is left. Managers say they appreciate you and respect you but actions are quite different. It does not have to be spoken but is already understood that you are a disposable unit. It is sad that they are so concerned with the bottom line and not the quality of the product.

review_title: This Career College is under investigation by the Federal Government, practices are less than professional.
pros: you can help lower income students get an education
cons: low level students, high turnover of teachers, corporate profits come before educational standards, students rule teachers through fear of feedback to keep jobs, all that matters is student numbers. Overall quality of programs is low and intellectual quality of students is generally lower than it should be. Many come from backgrounds with great social and emotional problems. Work load is extremely high with little support or funding.

pros:
Staff is friendly (well non-management) --- you get a sense of "You are in this together"
Free food whenever student events are held at campus
cons:
Lower than average wages
Budget seems to be focused more on external apperances at Westwood compared to internal improvement. This means money will go toward an xbox 360 for student lounge first before updated software to teach for class.

review_title: Apply Only if Your Background is in Design and Business!!!
pros:
Pay is great
Some faculty and staff are really helpful, caring and supportive
Depending on your teaching area, you will always have courses to teach
cons:
High Turn-Over rate in all departments
Depending on your teaching area, you may not have courses to teach
Some department chairs do not work well with some instructors

pros: Westwood College is a great company!  Fantastic, engaged, intelligent employees who really value what they do and the contribution they make to helping people be successful.  I worked directly with the executive team and found them to be very committed and ethical in an environment where the industry was being maligned on a daily basis.  I was proud to work for them.
cons: For me, the only downside was relocating the office to lengthen my commute.  It was also difficult to see downsizing during a rough time with the economy and the education industry as a whole.

job_title: Senior Admissions Representative in Douglasville, GA
pros: My coworkers were mostly awesome people who really cared about the students, however, burn out can take it's toll on everyone.
cons: Those in power didn't really care about the students and those who did care had no power to change things or do what needed to be done or make the needed decisions. Those with the most power put people with little to no experience in management positions so that they could be pawns and "yes" men because they had no actual education, training or experience to know any better.

review_title: Great place for a second career
pros: I joined Westwood as an adjunct and was promoted after one year. I had been forced to retire from the public school system after I turned sixty. Westwood has a great diversity of students, which allows me to use my special talents in special education and teaching English as a second language learners. I have enjoyed full support from the administration. This has allowed me to introduce an expanded curriculum in mathematics and the science classes.
cons: I think that more thought should be given when planning scheduling for mathematics class. Five and six hour math classes don't work. The classes need to be broken into two class periods.

pros: I worked in Admissions for the online campus, and for the most part, the people I worked with were awesome. The middle management genuinely wants you to succeed, and they do that with very structured, well-coordinated training.
cons: Upper management and the executive division were both hot messes They over-budgeted, were completely oblivious to the down trend in the for-profit educational markets, and unfortunately, it cost about eighty people their jobs as a result of a corporate layoff.

review_title: You'll make great friends... but that's about it
pros: Great people that work there, pay is really good
cons: it will suck your soul, the school cost WAY too much, managers have no idea what they are doing, they run off all good reps and just hire new ones, completely number focused even though it is illegal. Also, there is no room for advancement or lateral movement what so ever.

review_title: It was very rewarding helping students earn a degree who may not have had a chance othewise.
pros: Getting to know students personally and helping them on their journey to earn their degree and change their lives.
cons: A lot of emphasis is placed on and enrollment being a "sale" where the human value and importance of education can be lost.

review_title: If you hit your metrics you will do great!
pros: Compensation, Office environment with the ability to leave your office if need be, friendly staff members, Majority of employees are always looking out for the students and their best interests which provides success for the student and the school
cons: Some members of management are two-faced and manipulative making it hard to withstand for a long time, Metrics are high even during a drought of a mindset that education is worth it

review_title: For-profit college internal struggle; Fantastic co-workers
pros: Co-workers were professional, courteous, kind. Hiring manager was laid back, easy to talk to. Not intimidating at all. Willing to work with my schedule to determine teaching schedule. Were open to me incorporating fresh ideas to the shared syllabus. Free parking at building for instructors.
cons: Training session was tiresome, but expected. It's hard to teach young people knowing that they are going into tremendous amounts of debt just to get a diploma from an unaccredited university. (Hiring managers typically only accept accredited colleges and universities when reviewing applicants.) Seeing the recruitment process first hand was sobering. Talk about a moral/ethical dilemma. I had to leave.

review_title: Lower level management means well, but the "C" level executives are a mess.
pros: The team managers (called Directors Of Admissions), were great and wanted to see everyone succeed. The leaders just above them were great as well.
cons: The executive team for Alta really are the ones who are responsible for the negativity involved in the company. When pressed about why Westwood was being sued (in a meeting with about 2000 employees there), the COO said, and I quote "Above my pay grade". Have never actually heard a bunch of employees literally "boo" one of their bosses.

review_title: I worked in admissions and as a trainer for over 3 years
pros: Really excellent training department when I was there.  They really make sure their employees know the job.  Also, this is one of the funnest places I ever worked, in terms of working with great co-workers.
cons: It's a nationally accredited university which means the education does little to nothing for the students we were enrolling. It's hard to stomach at the end of the day.  There are also aggressive sales tactics and clever ways we are taught to not tell students about the detriment of going to a nationally accredited college.

pros: There aren't any to give.
cons:
Low level students, they learned to manipulate management by threatening to leave if you don't do what they want. They also rule teachers through fear of feedback to keep jobs, this is what matters to the Dean and Program Chairs. 

The Campus President compared the programs to selling cars. The employees are deceptive and back stabbers. The program chair smile in my face while looking for my replacement. 

I worked crazy hours like 8:00 am to 10:30 pm.  They were angry when I wanted to discuss this issue. 

Overall quality is subpar. Tired of calling students who refused to show up for class. They are allowed an unusual amount of days out of class. All of them come from backgrounds with great social and emotional problems.

review_title: Not even close to acceptable.  Stay away. Period.
pros: Met some really nice people.
cons: They charge way too much to not education their students!  These poor students think they are "accepted" to a higher education institution, but whats really happening is Westwood is signing them up for lifetime debt for education that's definitely not worth the sticker price. Management could take quite a few lessons on how to manage and lead.  Directors do shady things to keep the school in operation.  Stay away from this place!  The pay is much lower then most higher education institutions, yet they charge about the same or more than reputable institutions.  So where's the money going??? Upper level management, that's where!

pros: Great place to learn and grow professionally because of peer collaboration. Sharing of ideas and integration of those ideas into processes is also a plus.
cons: Sometimes, there is so much work to be done, that colleagues are unaware of the work that others are doing, because there is no time to share that work.

pros: There are some great instructors there that teaches, and have 20+ years in the industry in which they teach. They are very professional as well.
cons: There are other employers who are not instructors that did not set examples concerning honest and ethical behaviors, they stole from the company thinking that they would never get caught. There was another issue as well, the school was not state accredited which is one reason why they are being sued and couple with the employee's steeling, Westwood College went under and had no choice but to close its' doors for good here in Atlanta, GA.

review_title: okay place if you can get over their unethical business practices
pros: great place to start in the field of instructional design or educational technology. Good practice.
cons: One major con is that once you have Westwood on your CV, it is difficult to get a job anywhere else. People all around the area distrust Westwood because of their terrible ethical standards. Management is micromanaging and looks over your shoulder at everything you are doing. If you are in the bathroom "too long" you get suspicious looks from your manager. It is a culture of distrust.

review_title: Sunny at times, but mostly shady
job_title: Senior Admission Representative in Chicago, IL
pros:
-Decent pay.  I got in when they were able to monetarily reward their admissions representatives for good performance.  New incoming employees may not think the pay is decent now that they have a new pay structure.  
-For the most part it was a fun atmosphere until they got into trouble for employing a few bad apples in their admissions and financial aid departments.  Then it felt like you were walking through a field of land mines.
-The career focused, small class sizes, accelerated format is a great fit for some people.
cons:
- Everything in admissions is scripted, so you will always feel on edge about saying exactly the right things in exactly the right way.  Ever since they got into trouble we were observed and secret shopped constantly.  
-Your calls are monitored, so expect to make 75 calls a day, and expect to answer to why you did not make that many the next day if you fail to do so.  The director of admissions will also record your calls and make sure you are following the phone script.  Periodically, they will send you recordings of your phone calls, so you must always be on your game.  
-There is major favoritism. As a newcomer, expect to call off of call sheets that are a couple of months old.  You will be calling prospects that the more senior representatives could not convert into students.  The quality of prospects you will receive will depend on your "numbers", so don't have a bad class because you will most likely be punished by not getting any quality prospects.  And then you will be grilled for your continued poor performance even though they know the types of leads they are providing you.          
-The school is very expensive.  Students leave with a lot more debt than if they went to a not for profit institution.  The Westwood College student default rate is extremely poor.  They target the low income, first generation college student and charge them extremely high tuition.     
-The benefits are not very good.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Worked with some great people that really cared about the students and worked hard
cons: The company stopped enrolling students therefore, it will be closing soon. There are some people that work for the company that should have left along time ago. They did not seem to care about the overall goal of the company.

pros:
I get along great with my team and director.
Ok pay.
Good PTO (if you can use it)
cons:
Goals are very un practical
late hours
AG suit-so enrolling and even 'career orientations' are very difficult...not sure IL campuses will be around in the near future...?
lots of un ethical tactics have to happen it seems to be successful
not enough leads-too many people-its like one carcus and 10 voltures. and then the leads get killed by feeling bombarded.

review_title: Working at Westwood was a horrible experience where they show no shame in taking advantage of people.
pros: One good thing about working for Westwood College Online is that they pay a decent wage and offer benefits health benefits.
cons: They do not care that employees feel that what they are doing is unethical.  They do not give good feedback on how to become a better representative when the representative continues to dial the phone and get hung up on for calling the same person for the 20th time.

review_title: The Job Title should be "Sales Person" and not "Admission Rep"
job_title: Admissions Representative in West Chicago, IL
pros:
You have your own office
Decent pay
cons:
Sales, sales and more sales
The school has a bed reputation
You are required to enroll as many as possible to meet your quota
Very stressful
Lots of micromanaging
Management has no idea what they're doing
I felt like i was doing something really wrong each time I enrolled someone to school
Overall, you have to be an sales person, who is good in selling a product no matter what to thrive there. I just don't think that sales and higher education should ever be mixed.

review_title: Career college working to provide world or experience to students
pros: Staff in both my previous department and current department truly care what happens to students and perform their jobs with the intent to help every student succeed.
cons: Alta does try to guess where issues may arise and sometimes puts too many restrictions upon itself rather than waiting for final legislation. They also tend to send program information and changes outin pieces rather than providing all of the necessary info to all campuses at the same time and before it might be a problem.

review_title: Aroller coaster ride! The company need solid direction and communication from the employees on improving.
job_title: Senior Admission Representative in Anaheim, CA
pros:
A check and benefits was the reason.  At first it was an opportunity until you get inside and see the
cold staff.
cons: High pressure, management got attitudes of "Who are you" Good old boy network and not connecting with the workers!

pros: I have worked at 2 campuses. Each campus had a great team. There was so much potential in each department. Great co-workers.
cons: Corporate management didn't seem to know what they were doing, which greatly affected us at the campus levels. Each decision by management brought down morale. They thought they were doing better but in reality they were putting salt on old (and new) wounds.

review_title: It was great at first, until they get tired of you
job_title: Student Services Advisor in Upland, CA
pros: Compensation was pretty good for a for-profit school. And as long as you work there, you get to go to school there for free, minus book fees.
cons: Even if you're doing a good job and being productive, if your manager or the president of the campus are tired of you, or seeing you everyday, you might as well start looking elsewhere.

pros: Decent salaries, good people at the campus level, good programs, solid faculty
cons: Top management is too concerned about profits and not about their people.  Executive management making bad decisions.  Nothing really different about the system as compared to other for profits.  No pay increases 2 out of last 3 years and employees told to do more with less.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: fun environment, lots of training, talented individuals, good benefits, good recognition programs, departments work well together- lots of internal customer service
cons: not appreciated, work your butt off, make sure to negotiate a good salary when you start- if not, your screwed, nationally accredited school- has a bad reputation which is no fault of your own, but you are left defending the school all the time to students, parents and other professionals/companies

review_title: Been here for 7 years and it's been a very good experience
pros: The organization has a great mission and has helped thousands of students get the skills and training to find meaningful work. It is a collaborative environment and there is an openness to trying out new ideas.
cons: The organization has gone trough a lot of regulatory and legal issues and at times has lost focus. This has also impacted the culture and we've seen a lot of great people leave the organization.

pros: The salary  for IT is good but you will work a lot of off hours.  And don't even think about asking for PTO time for all the weekend and nights you will work.
cons:
Besides all the bad press and lawsuits, the management is a joke.  I have yet to meet an inspirational manager.  
The 401k contribution is depressing and almost not worth contributing to at all.
Long hours that will impact your nights and weekends
No compassion from leadership
No opportunity to move around the company
Lies, lies, and more lies

pros: Great people, awesome to support students achieve their goals and provide access to a college education for students regardless of their financial status.
cons: Decisions in key strategic areas were not made in order to keep the doors open. It is unfortunate so many students are now deprived of access to a great education.

pros: There are no pros this place is a joke.
cons: As a graphic/web design student, they didn't have enough staff for my major and they didn't have enough web classes either. Plus now they are saying that they're no longer going to have the graphic design program at the damage campus. Gee I wonder why, probably bc the school is not accredited through the region which hurts your chances at a few companies. Plus the school is way overpriced. I am over 90K in student loans bc I had to take out a few grants in order to stay there. They don't care about their students. Stay away.

review_title: Not A Place Where You Can Succeed
job_title: Admissions Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Every now and then you actually feel like you are helping someone.
cons: Success in this position is next to impossible without playing company politics and being fed.  The standards are so unrealistic, they will push you to enroll anyone. They count on you losing 50% of your enrollments and practically want you to lie to keep students in school 14 days.  Instructors are disgruntled and under paid. Resources for students are non existent.  This school will not last.

review_title: Not what I expected, good start to gaining experience but not a place for long term employment
pros: Being able to fall back on your co-workers for assistance, location is safe. Reimbursement is fine for those at entry level.
cons: More like telemarketing than admissions. Not helping future students gain an education but more like selling the product. College has a bad reputation, having to defend the college. High stress. Not being able to help current or future students with their academics, have to be more concerned about getting them enrolled and keeping them enrolled whatever it takes.

pros: Great co workers, working with students.
cons: Really don't want people to stay a long time, Took away long term benefits. Student numbers is all they care about. not the quality of the students, Admissions people lie about wages and jobs. No raises for last 4 years. Money from one program goes to other programs not back into one that's making it.

pros: The salary and benefits were good.
cons: As a Admissions representative you had to lie to get people to attend a school where the degree was not recognized, the cost for the programs outside of computers was not worth the  money as the ROI was not there. You don't need a degree for a career that will only pay you $12.00 an hour and have over $60K in debt.

review_title: Sweatshop environment, low ethics, encouraged manipulate prospective students.
pros: If you are good with people this is a place you can use your skills, but there are many more places that will treat you better and pay better too
cons: Poor products, deceptive marketing techniques, incomplete training, no long-term invesment with their own people

review_title: This is not a kiddy college
pros: Westwood has been a great place to apply my prior experience in teaching nontraditional students. I feel like the students that attend here really want to improve their lives and that the faculty is here to help make that happen. The training and community at Westwood is terrific.
cons: I don't see a clear path for advancement with in the organization. There is no internal posting system for openings.

review_title: My experience at Westwood College has been rewarding.
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Westwood College is the fact you interact with a diverse and intelligent student body and the environment/atmosphere is inviting.
cons: Some of the reasons for not working at Westwood College includes their marginal salaries and advancement may not come as quickly as one may desire.

pros: Faculty and staff genuinely care about the students despite their treatment from management.
cons: College worries more about money than they do about students. Retention is important, but this campus president takes it to an extreme and is known for going off on rampages. Forces faculty and staff to call any student who misses a class. Students receive many calls and respond that they feel 'stalked.' Rumors are constantly heard about the colleges financial struggles and possible campus closures. Definitely an environment of fear.

pros:
Good pay
Decent benefits
Some great co-workers
Tuition assistance is available
cons:
It's a sales job as much as they tell you it's all about the student. 
HIGH turnover rate- about a third of employees have been there less than a year.
Makes you doubt your own integrity because you can lose your job if a certain number of students don't start.
School has a bad reputation and just tries to shove it under the rug. 
Stressful

review_title: Eh. They are going to shut down soon anyway.
pros: My Admissions Director was the main reason I stayed for so long. The man CARES about his employees. Don't see that much in sales.
cons:
Cut throat. And when I say cut throat I don't mean fellow employees jump on your leads every so often 'by mistake'. I mean you better call your leads like 500 times to get that answer because if you don't...you have like 8 other reps calling FROM YOUR SCHOOL. Your Assistant Director? The one whos the 'biggest team player'? Yeah..he's got time tables/Outlook reminders of when to call all of his Admin. reps leads. People who have been there for more than a couple years know the tricks. If you don't-you'll sink quick. The vets want you out so more lead rotation goes in their favor. More new people-more leads for them. Get ready too-youll have rules but vets don't follow them. I would suggest you play dumb and play their game. "oh im sorry I called him by accident! I enrolled him because I had NO idea!...you can have my lead list if you want!' (that have already been called 50+ times)

Programs WW SAYS they offer...and the ones they actually do. If they don't have enough kids-they cancel the program for that term. Oh and expect to be selling over 80k/year programs When these kids/adults will MAYBE make...12 bucks an hour? At a high? Good luck convincing because a lot of these people cant even pay for a 2.50 blue line ride let alone make payments for school (which by the way-WILL happen. Rare they get most/all covered) And the Career Services? Only will help your student get a job IF it helps them. There is a certain time span they have. If the student doesn't fall in it-oh well. They will just avoid them and not return their calls. Then they will cancel/drop because well...cant get a job. 

The hours aren't great. 8pm at night? Really? 

Regardless-for profit is going to Hell. Westwood is going under...so if you want a OK paycheck to tie you over for a bit, go for it.

review_title: Don't work here if you care about Education
pros: Decent pay. Close to home. Got to know some good people who processed loans and such. They flew me to Denver for training too.
cons:
I accepted a position there because I genuinely care about students. I have a degree in education and when the economy tanked, this was a good option. Sometimes I wonder if that's the only reason they hired me--so they could tell their critics that their staff has education experience.

At the beginning of every semester, there are these intense meetings for 14 days straight, at least an hour or more each day. All of the department heads would have to attend. The purpose of that meeting? To figure out why student A, B or C hasn't processed their paperwork for their loans/grants/military benefits yet. Why 14 days? Because that's the magic number of days that the federal government requires a student to be attending class before they will send the loan and grant money to a college. The saying was "We need asses in classes."

After 14-days, I was told to stop caring about those students I had just recruited and start recruiting new ones for the next session. The only reason I should be talking to old students is to get names and phone numbers of new people to recruit. 

We received incentive pay for meeting and exceeding recruiting goals. It’s technically against the law for any school receiving federal funds to have quotas for their admissions recruiters. Westwood will tell you that the goals are “incentives.” If it’s just that, then why are there trophies and plaques and exotic trips for reps who have the highest recruiting numbers? 

Westwood has been trying to get Regional Accreditation (the highest standard available) for years. Whenever the accreditation people would visit, we'd have to take down our plaques and trophies.

Everything that we did was for the ultimate goal of getting that big fat loan check from the government or a bank. I felt like I was brainwashed. Every time I questioned a recruiting tactic, they would tell me that I was being to "cerebral". 

My director told me to say things like, "Oh, you said your 7th grade English teacher really supports you going to college. Do you think she would co-sign a loan for you?"

In the end, they fired me for not meeting my sales goals. That was the best thing that could have happened to me. I look back and I feel like I sold my soul.

review_title: This school is morally bankrupt and their only goal is to take people's money - NOT to educate."
